description:
An anthology of four standalone films encompassing different genres.

Tsukumo (Possessions)
A lost wanderer seeks refuge inside a shrine where he finds lots of possessed objects.

Hi no Youjin (Combustible)
The movie depicts the events that led to the Great Fire of Meireki which destroyed more than half of the Japanese capital city of Edo.

Gambo (Gambo)
A young girl asks a white bear to defeat a vicious ogre that is kidnapping the first born girls of a small village.

Buki yo Saraba (A Farewell to Weapons)
In a post-apocalyptic future, a group of soldiers is sent to a ghost city to destroy an automated sentry.

Note:
- Tsukumo and Hi no Youjin received advanced individual screenings at the Annecy Animation Film Festival in June 2012.
- Hi no Youjin and Buki yo Saraba are based on Katsuhiro Ootomo's manga of the same name, whereas Tsukumo and Gambo are original stories.

tags.name: Anthology
tags.description: A collection of separate works collated into a single release.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Full CGI
tags.description: Almost entirely created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Samurai
tags.description: Prominently features warriors of medieval Japanese nobility bound by a code of honor.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kojimorimoto) | [Website](http://www.kojimorimoto.com)

Fan of anime such as [Lupin the 3rd](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/Lupin-the-3rd/) and [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/Future-Boy-Conan/), after graduating from the Osaka Designers' college, he joined [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) and soon after Studio [Annapuru](https://anilist.co/studio/583/Annapuru). He wanted to work with esteemed Director [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/Osamu-Dezaki) since [Gamba's Adventure](https://anilist.co/anime/5267/Gambas-Adventure/) was particularly striking to him.

Interested in effects animation, he cites [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/Yoshinori-Kanada) and [Kazuhide Tomonaga](https://anilist.co/staff/110219/Kazuhide-Tomonaga) as major influences. He had his first breakthrough as animator on [Space Adventure Cobra](https://anilist.co/anime/2451/Space-Adventure-Cobra/) and [Golgo 13: The Professional](https://anilist.co/anime/1760/), in which his effects work and fun character animation was highly praised. Later his work became increasingly more experimental, combining his animation with intricate art design and CGI.

During his period at Annapuru he befriended [Takashi Nakamura](https://anilist.co/staff/102031/Takashi-Nakamura) and the two worked on several projects together even after leaving the studio. [Katsuhiro Ootomo](https://anilist.co/staff/96872/Katsuhiro-Ootomo) recognized his talent and Morimoto became a key figure in many of his works. He debuted as Director on [Robot Carnival](https://anilist.co/anime/2182/Robot-Carnival/).

In 1985 he founded [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/) alongside former Ghibli producer [Eiko Tanaka](https://anilist.co/staff/103607/Tanaka-Eiko). He would later leave the studio in 2011.

Married to [Atsuko Fukushima](https://anilist.co/staff/118789/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

CG animator, director, and composite artist.

In 2014, he helped establish the CG animation studio [Buemon](https://anilist.co/studio/6300/Buemon) led by the 3DCG staff of Sunrise Nerima Studio.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kojimorimoto) | [Website](http://www.kojimorimoto.com)

Fan of anime such as [Lupin the 3rd](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/Lupin-the-3rd/) and [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/Future-Boy-Conan/), after graduating from the Osaka Designers' college, he joined [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) and soon after Studio [Annapuru](https://anilist.co/studio/583/Annapuru). He wanted to work with esteemed Director [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/Osamu-Dezaki) since [Gamba's Adventure](https://anilist.co/anime/5267/Gambas-Adventure/) was particularly striking to him.

Interested in effects animation, he cites [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/Yoshinori-Kanada) and [Kazuhide Tomonaga](https://anilist.co/staff/110219/Kazuhide-Tomonaga) as major influences. He had his first breakthrough as animator on [Space Adventure Cobra](https://anilist.co/anime/2451/Space-Adventure-Cobra/) and [Golgo 13: The Professional](https://anilist.co/anime/1760/), in which his effects work and fun character animation was highly praised. Later his work became increasingly more experimental, combining his animation with intricate art design and CGI.

During his period at Annapuru he befriended [Takashi Nakamura](https://anilist.co/staff/102031/Takashi-Nakamura) and the two worked on several projects together even after leaving the studio. [Katsuhiro Ootomo](https://anilist.co/staff/96872/Katsuhiro-Ootomo) recognized his talent and Morimoto became a key figure in many of his works. He debuted as Director on [Robot Carnival](https://anilist.co/anime/2182/Robot-Carnival/).

In 1985 he founded [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/) alongside former Ghibli producer [Eiko Tanaka](https://anilist.co/staff/103607/Tanaka-Eiko). He would later leave the studio in 2011.

Married to [Atsuko Fukushima](https://anilist.co/staff/118789/).
The founder and representative of [Yamato Works](https://anilist.co/studio/7090/).
The founder and representative of [Yamato Works](https://anilist.co/studio/7090/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/hidekazuohara)

After graduating from the Department of Industrial Chemistry at Miyakonojo Technical College he joined [Topcraft](https://anilist.co/studio/363/) (later [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)), where he partook in the production of [Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](https://anilist.co/anime/572/). Afterwards he turned to CM production and joined Studio Arrow and later became freelance. Today he collaborates often with [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/), working on many of their projects as animator, character designer and director.

(Source: AniDB)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大友克洋) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuhiro_Otomo) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/oyaji_shu)

Best-known as the creator of the manga series [Akira](https://anilist.co/manga/30664/), and its 1988 [film adaptation](https://anilist.co/anime/47/).

While he was in high school he was fascinated with movies, often taking a three-hour train ride during school holidays just to see them. After having graduated high school in 1973, he left Miyagi, heading to Tokyo with the hopes of becoming a mangaka. He made his debut later on the same year with a manga adaptation of Prosper Mérimée's short novel Mateo Falcone, titled A Gun Report. In 1979, after writing multiple short-stories for the magazine Action, Ootomo created his first science-fiction work, titled Fireball. Although the manga was never completed, it is regarded as a milestone in Ootomo's career, containing many of the same themes he would later explore in [Doumu](https://anilist.co/manga/31215/), which began serialization in January 1980 and ran for two years until completed.

In 1982, Ootomo made his anime debut as character designer on [Harmagedon](https://anilist.co/anime/1626/). After this Ootomo began working on Akira, which would become his most acclaimed and famous work. The manga took eight years to complete and would eventually culminate in 2000 pages of artwork.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大友克洋) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuhiro_Otomo) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/oyaji_shu)

In 1982, Ootomo made his anime debut as character designer on [Harmagedon](https://anilist.co/anime/1626/). After this Ootomo began working on Akira, which would become his most acclaimed and famous work. The manga took eight years to complete and would eventually culminate in 2000 pages of artwork.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ando_beanjam)

Pioneered the cel shaded, expressive look that distinguishes [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/)'s CG work.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大友克洋) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuhiro_Otomo) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/oyaji_shu)

Best-known as the creator of the manga series [Akira](https://anilist.co/manga/30664/), and its 1988 [film adaptation](https://anilist.co/anime/47/).

After this Ootomo began working on Akira, which would become his most acclaimed and famous work. The manga took eight years to complete and would eventually culminate in 2000 pages of artwork.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Veteran animator specialized in effects animation.
